content: Added cover art.
Edited to move the topics initially given at the beginning of the statement ("Topic: A* algorithm, Pathfinding, Heuristic search") to the tags.
After the classes I decided to add special test for this f-value equality case.
how does it happen that you do not get "2 536" before last line in last validator?

Many thanks for the ACC and improvements in the description.

Given the experience, I'm already starting to write puzzle for the next week's lab ;-).
(I won't tell you what, it'll be a surprise :P)

From Arad to Bucarest via Timisoara? I've seen this before ;-)

I'm approving, but wouldn't mind:
* having N, E, S, G on a single line
* having h-values on a single line
* having the f-value in the statement either defined or reworded.

Also (same as Stilgart), I'm of the opinion that the task is NOT "compute the shortest path", rather "trace a canonical A* execution".

There are a few things to fix before approval of this puzzle.

First, you cannot assume that people have sufficient knowledge of the A* algorithm. At the very least, give a link to some external resource on this topic.
Moreover, I think that the "f-value" has to be defined within the statement.

Then, the tests/validators can be improved. I suggest that you add a very easy test/validator with a 2-nodes graph. Also, it might be better to swap validators 1 and 2 (so that test/validator 2 both check the case where the starting node is not 0).

I also think that you can remove the sentence "The given heuristic is admissible and consistent." since it is quite technical and not so relevant. We are asked here to output the sequence of nodes that the A* algorithm will consider, and so it doesn't really matter whether the path between s and g is the shortest one.
Its the task I want to give my AI students on Monday, so I beg you to review it ASAP ;-).

My program provided the same output, so I approve the puzzle right now as you asked for it.
However all the public testcases start at node 0, so I recommend adding another testcase (I only approve because I could add such a validator even after approval and you need it for tomorrow).

OK, many thanks.

I assumed that anyone can do "google->A star", since we cannot make hyperlinks in puzzles (I still wonder why?). this looks stupid and not very helpful (but I added wiki url).

I was thinking about extremely easy case, but abandon the idea. 2 nodes make no sense but I added example with 3. Also validators swapped as suggested.

Last statement is true, but I think that clarifies some possible issues, e.g. what to do when we did not found goal.

I like "trace a canonical A* execution" statement - added to the description.
I also overcame my lazyness, and put all number in single lines as you proposed.
I'm smelling the wumpus stench from here already.

Ties in the queue should be solved using the id's ordering (see the last  line of the statement).
Thus the node 1 (goal) is dequeued before the node 2.
ok, i added qsort to my open nodes array, but i think that problem is that execution of A* can be canonical while depending on non-canonical priority queue implementation

So what is canonical  priority queue implementation? 
Random ordering? Hard to get this on a puzzle...

i don't know how to clarify this
you can check my "canonical" A* implementation here: http://rosettacode.org/wiki/A*_search_algorithm#C
Yeah, but that's not  'general', i.e. graph-based, bud grid-based ;-)
nope! have a closer look, my stops array (stop is equivalent to node in this excersize) is 1-dimensional
Sorry, maybe my bad - I just took a  short glance. It's C so it's unreadable by default :P.

That's the idea - I like it! But sorry ;-).
Base algorithm testing before multi.

Thanks, I just switched test02 with validator02 (cats are lazy creatures^^).

It will probably go as it is i.e. pending.
I have to start preparing exercises quicker (given avg. acceptance time, half year at least :P)
